framework_metadata.title: Enhanced Relationship Management Framework
framework_metadata.description: Comprehensive framework for analyzing and managing relationships with position templates, scenarios, and tactical guidance

core_concepts.text: A relationship is a running series of engagements between two parties. Even if no engagements have occurred, as long as you are aware of the other party, a relationship can be calculated. An engagement is defined as a direct interaction between two parties where some form of communication is exchanged.

The three components of a relationship are Desire, Power, and Rapport. Desire is the amount one party wishes to engage with the other, based on the party's goal. High Desire means one party wants something from the other, while Low Desire means one party wants nothing from the other.

Relative Power is the capacity of one party to exert its will on the other, based on Respect, Harm, and Aid. Overall Relative Power is zero-sum - high power in one area is nullified by low power in another. Respect is the power from having high standing in the other party's eyes.

Rapport is the ease with which one party can engage the other based on their history of engagements. High rapport means you've had many positive engagements, neutral means few interactions or many mixed interactions, and low rapport means many negative engagements.

From the analyzer's perspective, there are twelve types of relationships based on the combination of Desire (High/Low), Power (High/Even/Low), and Rapport (High/Low): High Desire-High Power-High Rapport (Dominant), High Desire-High Power-Low Rapport (Subjugative), High Desire-Even Power-High Rapport (Collaborative), High Desire-Even Power-Low Rapport (Compromising), High Desire-Low Power-High Rapport (Appealing), High Desire-Low Power-Low Rapport (Supplicating), Low Desire-High Power-High Rapport (Protective), Low Desire-High Power-Low Rapport (Dismissive), Low Desire-Even Power-High Rapport (Resistant), Low Desire-Even Power-Low Rapport (Avoidant), Low Desire-Low Power-High Rapport (Defensive), and Low Desire-Low Power-Low Rapport (Accommodating).

position_templates.description: High Desire, High Power, High Rapport - You want something, have significant leverage, and have strong positive history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Direct engagement with confidence. Use rapport to enhance your power advantage. Lead with value and relationship strength.
tactical_priorities: Lead with relationship strength and shared history
Use power judiciously, letting rapport do the heavy lifting
Emphasize mutual benefit and shared success
Be prepared for collaborative resistance rather than hostile resistance
warning_signs: Over-relying on power when rapport could work better
Failing to acknowledge the positive history

position_templates.description: High Desire, High Power, Low Rapport - You want something and have significant leverage, but have negative history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Direct but respectful engagement. Use power judiciously to avoid resistance. Build rapport during the process.
tactical_priorities: Use power as backup, not primary tool
Work to build rapport during engagement
Be prepared for pushback despite power advantage

position_templates.description: High Desire, Even Power, High Rapport - You want something, have equal standing, and have strong positive history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Collaborative partnership approach. Leverage rapport to create win-win solutions. Focus on mutual success.
tactical_priorities: Use rapport to facilitate open communication
Focus on creative solutions that benefit both parties
Build on positive history and trust
warning_signs: Taking advantage of the positive relationship
Assuming agreement based on rapport alone

position_templates.description: High Desire, Even Power, Low Rapport - You want something but have equal standing and negative history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Collaborative negotiation with clear value exchange. Focus on mutual benefit while acknowledging past issues.
warning_signs: Rushing to close without proper negotiation

position_templates.description: High Desire, Low Power, High Rapport - You want something and have little leverage, but have strong positive history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Leverage rapport to compensate for power disadvantage. Use relationship strength to create opportunities.
tactical_priorities: Lead with relationship strength and shared history
Use rapport to create value and opportunities
Find ways to increase your value to them
warning_signs: Over-relying on rapport without building value

position_templates.description: High Desire, Low Power, Low Rapport - You want something but have little leverage and negative history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Build value and rapport before making requests. Use indirect approaches and focus on damage repair.
tactical_priorities: Focus on building rapport and value
Find ways to increase your value to them

position_templates.description: Low Desire, High Power, High Rapport - You don't want engagement but have leverage and strong positive history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Gentle deflection using rapport. Use relationship strength to maintain boundaries without damaging rapport.
tactical_priorities: Maintain positive relationship while saying no
Offer alternatives that preserve the relationship

position_templates.description: Low Desire, High Power, Low Rapport - You don't want engagement but have leverage and negative history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Minimal engagement with clear boundaries. Use power to maintain distance without concern for rapport damage.
tactical_priorities: Use power to deflect unwanted requests
Be prepared to say no firmly
warning_signs: Allowing them to build rapport against your interests

position_templates.description: Low Desire, Even Power, High Rapport - You don't want engagement and have equal standing, but have strong positive history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Gentle resistance using rapport. Use relationship strength to deflect while preserving the positive connection.
tactical_priorities: Resist unwanted requests gently but firmly

position_templates.description: Low Desire, Even Power, Low Rapport - You don't want engagement and have equal standing with negative history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Defensive engagement with clear resistance. Avoid unnecessary concessions without concern for rapport damage.

position_templates.description: Low Desire, Low Power, High Rapport - You don't want engagement and have little leverage, but have strong positive history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Gentle resistance using rapport. Use relationship strength to deflect while preserving the positive connection.

position_templates.description: Low Desire, Low Power, Low Rapport - You don't want engagement and have little leverage with negative history
position_templates.recommended_approach: Minimal engagement with strategic resistance. Focus on damage control without concern for rapport damage.

scenarios.title: Salary Negotiation with Current Employer
scenarios.description: You want a significant raise but work for a company that's been cutting costs
recommended_tactics: Build case for your value before requesting

decision_tree.initial_question: Do you have strong performance evidence?

branches.action: Lead with achievements and value demonstration
branches.next_question: Is company in growth or cost-cutting mode?

branches.action: Focus on building value first, delay request

scenarios.title: Client Pushing for Discount on Large Project
scenarios.description: Long-term client wants 20% discount on major project due to budget constraints
key_factors: Project profitability at different price points
recommended_tactics: Acknowledge their constraints while maintaining value
Offer alternative solutions (phased delivery, scope adjustment)
Prepare to walk away if necessary

branches.action: Find creative compromise that preserves relationship
branches.next_question: Can you adjust scope without losing profit?

branches.action: Maintain firm position, be prepared to lose client

scenarios.title: Vendor Demanding Payment Terms Change
scenarios.description: Key supplier wants to change from net-30 to net-15 payment terms

branches.action: Use competitive pressure to maintain current terms
branches.next_question: Can you afford to switch suppliers?

decision_trees.title: Engagement Type Selection
decision_trees.description: How to choose between offensive, defensive, or competitive engagement
decision_trees.root_question: What is your primary goal in this engagement?

branches.sub_question: Do they want something from you?

branches.condition: You want to avoid giving them something
branches.sub_question: Do you have power in this relationship?

decision_trees.title: Tactic Selection Based on Character
decision_trees.description: How to choose the most effective tactic based on the other party's character
decision_trees.root_question: What is their primary character vulnerability?

sub_branches.condition: Dim - slow to understand complex arguments
sub_branches.approach: Complicate arguments, use technical jargon, overwhelm with information
Introduce unknown negative outcomes, emphasize risks they haven't considered
Make claims they can't refute, cite sources they can't verify

sub_branches.condition: Empathetic - easily moved by others' feelings
sub_branches.approach: Make them feel bad for not helping, emphasize your suffering or need

sub_branches.condition: Insecure - doubts their own worth or capabilities
sub_branches.approach: Suggest inadequacy, imply they're not good enough to refuse

sub_branches.condition: Egotistic - needs to feel important or superior
sub_branches.approach: Suggest your position glorifies them, make them feel important for helping

decision_trees.title: Power Building Strategy
decision_trees.description: How to build power when you're in a weak position
decision_trees.root_question: What type of power do you need to build?

branches.condition: Respect power - they need to value you more
branches.sub_question: What's your current standing with them?

sub_branches.condition: Low standing - they don't value you
Medium standing - they value you somewhat

branches.condition: Harm power - you need ability to hurt their interests

sub_branches.condition: Direct leverage - you can directly impact their goals
actions: Show you can hurt their interests

sub_branches.condition: Indirect leverage - you can influence others who matter
actions: Build relationships with their key stakeholders

branches.condition: Aid power - you need ability to help their interests

sub_branches.condition: Direct help - you can directly advance their goals
actions: Make yourself essential to their success

sub_branches.condition: Indirect help - you can connect them to resources

tactical_templates.title: Offensive Engagement Template
tactical_templates.description: Standard structure for when you want something and they don't

tactics: Gauge their desire level after tactics

success_indicators: They suggest modifications rather than rejection

tactical_templates.title: Defensive Engagement Template
tactical_templates.description: Standard structure for when they want something and you don't

tactics: Don't allow positive atmosphere to develop
Reject their framing of the situation
Maintain neutral or slightly negative tone
Let them lose steam during their pitch
Deliver firm resistance with clear reasoning
End the engagement prematurely if needed

failure_indicators: They bring in others to pressure you

tactical_templates.title: Competitive Engagement Template
tactical_templates.description: Standard structure for when both parties want something from each other

tactics: Acknowledge their goal with minimal concession
Check desire levels after each exchange

failure_indicators: One party feels taken advantage of

analysis_framework.text: Analyzing for engagement means gaining an understanding of the other party's position so that you can optimize your position before engaging. This involves analyzing Engagement Desire, Relative Power, Rapport, and Character Vulnerabilities.

Engagement Desire is assessing the mental decision one comes to about a prospective request based on the request's effect on their goals and resources. This differs from overall Relationship desire - one could have high relationship desire but low engagement desire for a specific unfavorable request.

The components of desire are Value (how a request affects their relevant goal) and Resources (what one has to accomplish their goal with). Goals can be to acquire something, maintain something, or dispose of something. Resources can be tangible (money) or intangible (time).

The Engagement Desire Matrix uses scores from 3 (high) to -1 (negative) for both Value and Cost. Cost is subtracted from Value to give the Desire level between 4 (Desperate for) and -4 (Desperate to avoid). Value scores: 3=High (will satisfy goal), 2=Medium (will reasonably further goal), 1=Low (will slightly further goal), 0=None (will not further goal), -1=Negative (will detract from goal).

Relative Power Analysis examines three components: Respect (power from having high standing), Harm (power to negatively affect the other party's goals or resources), and Aid (power to positively affect the other party's goals or resources). Each can be High, Even, or Low relative to the other party.

Rapport Analysis examines three components: Number of engagements (how many times you've directly communicated), Nature of engagements (positive, neutral, or negative), and Comfort level of engagements (shallow, moderate, or deep). Deep engagements involve personal and private communications about identity and mission.

Character Vulnerability Analysis identifies traits of the other party that allow you to alter their perception of Value and Cost. Types include Intellectual vulnerabilities (dim, naive, uninformed) and Emotional vulnerabilities (empathetic, insecurity, egotistic). These can be exploited during engagement.

preparation_framework.text: Long-term adjustments to improve your position include increasing Relative Power through Respect, Harm, and Aid. For low or even power: build rapport to increase your importance, gain means to harm/benefit them, or neutralize their means. For high power: maintain your sources and resist their attempts.

Engagement Tactics are techniques used during engagement to adjust the other party's desire. These include Exploitation (using character flaws), Persuasion (constructing arguments to change perception), and Manipulation (provoking fear of your power). Each can be used offensively or defensively.

Exploitation uses the other party's character flaws to change their desire level. Intellectual exploitation targets vulnerability to deceit: for dim people, complicate arguments; for naive people, introduce unknown negative consequences; for uninformed people, make claims they can't refute. Emotional exploitation targets vulnerability to baiting: for empathetic people, make them feel bad; for insecure people, suggest inadequacy; for egotistic people, suggest your position glorifies them.

Persuasion constructs arguments to change how the other party perceives the effect to their goals and resources. True Offensive Persuasion talks them into seeing your request as more beneficial and requiring fewer resources. True Defensive Persuasion talks them into seeing their request as less helpful and more costly. False persuasion (begging/pleading) is only available when certain character flaws are present and immediately gives them power over you.

Manipulation constructs arguments to alter desire by provoking fear of your power. Offensive Manipulation uses fear to make your request more desirable; Defensive Manipulation uses fear to make their request less desirable. This can be done through Rapport (losing standing), Harm (hurting their goals), or Aid (not furthering their goals). Aid power threatens to take away existing help rather than offering quid pro quo.

engagement_framework.text: Engagement structures vary by type: Offensive (you want something, they want nothing), Competitive (you both want something), and Defensive (they want something, you want nothing). Each has distinct Opening, Middle Game, and End Game phases with specific tactics for each phase.

Offensive engagement structure: Opening includes Greeting (deliver formalities) and Orientation (present situation without pitching). Middle Game includes Pitch Softener (acknowledge resistance points), Pitch (deliver request), Receive Resistance (listen completely), Counter-Resistance Tactics (employ exploitation/manipulation/persuasion), and Post-Tactic Check-up (gauge desire level). End Game includes Close (obtain concurrence) and Post-Close Soothing (thanks and encouragement).

Competitive engagement structure: Opening includes Greeting and Orientation. Middle Game includes Pitch Softener (acknowledge their goal with minimal concession), Pitch (deliver maximum pitch), Resist Pre-Counter-Offer Tactics, Receive Counter-Offer (listen completely), Counter Counter-Offer Tactics, and Post-Tactic Check-up. End Game includes Close and Post-Close Soothing.

Defensive engagement structure: Opening includes Reject Greeting (don't allow positive atmosphere) and Obfuscate Orientation (reject their framing). Middle Game includes Hyperbolize Pitch Softener (over-concur with resistance points), Receive Pitch (they lose steam), Deliver Resistance (employ tactics), and Reject Count-Resistance Tactics (refute their counters). End Game includes Obfuscate Close (resist concurrence) and Disengage (end prematurely).

The winner of an engagement is determined by: who better understood the relationship, who more accurately analyzed the situation, who was more prepared before the engagement, who employed better tactics during the engagement, and who better adhered to the strategy. Success depends on comprehensive preparation and execution.
